channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: U.S. Says Main Thrust of Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Has Begun
item.description: Artillery duels flared along the southern front, as troops trained and equipped by the West pressed forward.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Where Russia Is on the Attack in Ukraine
item.description: Along the vast 600-mile front line, Russia is mostly playing defense. In the northeast, it is once again mounting fierce offensive operations.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Japanese Pop Star, Shinjiro Atae, Comes Out Publicly as Gay
item.description: “I don’t want people to struggle like me,” said Shinjiro Atae, making an announcement that is extremely unusual in conservative Japan.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shinjiro Atae, a J-pop idol, decided to come out publicly during a fan event on Wednesday night in Tokyo.

item.title: 70 Years Along the Zone Where the Korean War Never Ended
item.description: The Korean War Armistice was signed seventy years ago, separating the two Koreas and putting an end to the fighting, but not the war itself.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: The three-year Korean War was the single most traumatic event in modern Korean history.

item.title: Soldiers Attempt Mutiny in Niger, Its President’s Office Says
item.description: President Mohamed Bazoum has been one of the most reliable partners to many Western countries in a volatile region threatened by militant extremists and prone to coups.
item.dc:creator: Omar Hama Saley and Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Defenders of Niger’s president, Mohamed Bazoum, gather to show their support for him in the capital, Niamey, on Wednesday.

item.title: NatWest C.E.O. Resigns Amid Nigel Farage’s Feud With Coutts Bank
item.description: Nigel Farage, a political insurgent and ally of Donald J. Trump, exposed his bank for dropping him over “reputational risks.” Some analysts say he could parlay his situation into a comeback.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Nigel Farage speaking at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference, or CPAC, in National Harbor, Md., in March.

item.title: Wildfires in Greece Raise Fears of Tourism Collapse
item.description: The fiercest wildfires have hit only parts of a few islands. But the effects of climate change pose a far wider threat to Greece’s tourism industry.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Wildfire on Tuesday near the village of Gennadi on Rhodes. The Greek tourism minister has said visitors can still vacation elsewhere on the island.

item.title: War Brought Putin Closer to Africa. Now It’s Pushing Them Apart.
item.description: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia prepares to host African leaders at a summit, a collapsed grain deal and the uncertain fate of Wagner mercenaries have cast a shadow.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin with heads of African countries at a summit in Sochi, Russia, in 2019.

item.title: Israel’s Supreme Court to Hear Case Against Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul
item.description: The justices will hear petitions in September against a new law that curbs their own authority, which Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has pushed ahead despite Israel’s political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A protest in Tel Aviv on Monday evening after a vote by Parliament to limit powers of the Supreme Court.

item.title: Monsoon’s Fury Sours Romance of Wet Season Travel in India
item.description: Long considered a life-giving panacea, India’s rainy season has become more violent and unpredictable. It is upsetting many rhythms of life, among them, leisure travel.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: Heavy rains and flooding have inundated many parts of India, including the capital, New Delhi.

item.title: Rise of Far Right Leaves Germany’s Conservatives at a Crossroads
item.description: The surge of the Alternative for Germany party has shaken the country’s political establishment. But for mainstream conservatives, it has also prompted an acute identity crisis.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: A rally for the far-right Alternative for Germany party in front of the Reichstag in Berlin in October.

item.title: British Conservatives’ Commitment to Green Policy Is Tested
item.description: British conservatives kept a seat in a recent election by opposing an ultralow emissions zone, and some are now questioning ambitious emissions-reduction targets.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, center left, and Steve Tuckwell, center right. Mr. Tuckwell was elected to a seat formerly held by Boris Johnson.

item.title: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia Says He Will Resign
item.description: Mr. Hun Sen, whose party won stage-managed parliamentary elections on Sunday, has been prime minister of Cambodia since 1985. He said he would hand power to his son.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia voting at a polling station in southeast Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on Sunday.

item.title: Fiji’s Leader Declines Invitation to China, Saying He Tripped and Fell
item.description: The prime minister, wearing a bloodstained shirt, said he struck his head on a door. One analyst called it “very convenient.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mark Mitchell/NZ Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Fiji’s prime minister, Sitiveni Rabuka, in Wellington, New Zealand, last month. He has been trying to distance his country from China.

item.title: Biden Orders U.S. to Share Evidence of Russian War Crimes With Hague Court
item.description: The step signals a major shift in American policy and ends months of resistance by Pentagon officials who feared setting a precedent that could pave the way for the court to prosecute U.S. troops.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Tuesday. In recent days, he ordered the government to begin sharing evidence of Russian war crimes with the International Criminal Court.

item.title: A Dusty Fast-Food Costume Sets Off a Very Canadian Bidding War
item.description: The government of Alberta is auctioning off an adult-size suit shaped like a donair, a uniquely Canadian take on the gyro and doner kebab that is a beloved late-night staple in Nova Scotia.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: Premier Danielle Smith of Alberta with the donair costume in Edmonton last week. The costume, which the province commissioned for a public service ad warning against driving under the influence of cannabis, is being sold in an online auction.

item.title: Russia’s Online Censorship Has Surged During Ukraine War
item.description: A report from Citizen Lab laid out how much online censorship has increased on one of Russia’s biggest social media sites.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Adam Satariano and Aaron Krolik
item.media:description: The limits on VK, a large Russian social media site, are a part of a wider effort by the authorities to use technology to shape public opinion and crack down on dissent.

item.title: 52 Whales Die After Mass Stranding in Western Australia
item.description: A pod of nearly 100 pilot whales displayed unusual behavior before beaching themselves in Western Australia. More than 50 have died.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: ABC TV Australia, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Residents trying to rescue stranded whales at Cheynes Beach in Western Australia on Wednesday.

item.title: Some Russian Internet Trolls Turn Against Prigozhin After Wagner Uprising
item.description: The Kremlin, which has moved quickly to take down parts of Wagner leader Yevgeny Prigozhin’s empire, may seek to use his troll farms to its advantage, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Wagner mercenary chief, in Rostov-on-Don, Russia, last month.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russia seeks more troops.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser and Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Russian conscripts in Simferopol, Crimea, in April.

item.title: Odesa Cathedral Missile Attack Leaves Ukrainians Bereft
item.description: Odesa, a port city long beloved by travelers, had been largely spared the worst of the war, but that began changing this week.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Church workers inspecting the damage at the cathedral on Tuesday.

item.title: Judge Vacates Bowe Bergdahl’s Conviction and Dishonorable Discharge
item.description: The Army colonel overseeing the court-martial trial had applied for a job with the Trump-era Justice Department, raising the appearance of bias.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Bowe Bergdahl leaving a sentencing hearing at Fort Bragg, N.C., in 2017. A federal judge stopped short of shutting down the case.

item.title: Jill Biden Takes the 2024 Campaign to Paris in Another Overseas Appeal
item.description: As the United States officially rejoined UNESCO, the first lady delivered what sounded like a campaign message, saying the president had rebuilt bonds that frayed under his predecessor.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: Jill Biden with Audrey Azoulay, the director general of UNESCO, on Tuesday. “It’s important to see the U.S. back at the table,” Ms. Azoulay said.

item.title: Putin Plans China Visit as a Russian Leader Joins a North Korea Celebration
item.description: The visits reflect Moscow’s ongoing efforts to strengthen ties with Asian allies, given its isolation from the West.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A photo provided by state media showing President Xi Jinping of China and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow earlier this year.

item.title: Trevor Reed, Former U.S. Marine Who Was Detained in Russia, Is Injured While Fighting in Ukraine
item.description: Trevor Reed’s condition was not immediately clear. His decision to return to the region and volunteer to fight for Ukraine created some “exasperation” within the Biden administration, an administration official said.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: Trevor Reed, a former U.S. Marine, inside a Moscow courtroom in 2020. He was detained for nearly three years before he was released through a prisoner swap.

item.title: Israel’s Judicial Overhaul Will Set Off More Showdowns. But When?
item.description: The government’s vote to limit judicial power set off a night of street chaos. More showdowns are expected, but with Parliament about to recess, it is not clear when or in what form.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and lawmakers gather at the Knesset plenum to vote on a bill that would limit some Supreme Court power, in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: China has replaced its foreign minister, the world gets some good economic news, Israel faces a cliffhanger.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Qin Gang.

item.title: International Investigation into Mexico’s 43 Missing Students Ends
item.description: Members of an international panel said that the Mexican armed forces had repeatedly obstructed their efforts to investigate the 2014 disappearance and that they were leaving the country.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posters of some of the missing students in Mexico City last year.

item.title: Eight Convicted in 2016 Terrorist Bombings in Brussels
item.description: The series of attacks was the deadliest such assault in Belgian history. Six of the accused had already been convicted over terrorist attacks in Paris the previous year.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gathering in Place de la Bourse in Brussels in March 2016 at a makeshift memorial to victims of the terrorist attacks.

item.title: 34 Killed in Algerian Wildfires as Heat Waves Parch Mediterranean Region
item.description: Algeria’s government said that 10 of the dead were soldiers who were trying to rescue people from the fires, which have raged for days in a forested coastal region.
item.dc:creator: Rachid Sekkai and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Firefighters tried to extinguish a raging forest fire near a town in northwestern Tunisia, close to the Algerian border, on Monday.

item.title: Ales Pushkin, Dissident Artist in Belarus, Is Dead in Prison at 57
item.description: A “holy fool,” in his words, he railed against the repressive Lukashenko government, once with a pile of manure. He died under mysterious circumstances.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Belarusian security officers detained Ales Pushkin in July 1999 after he dumped a wheelbarrow full of manure outside the country’s presidential offices. A pitchfork pierced a photo of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.

item.title: Somber Mood Settles Over Israel’s Antigovernment Protesters
item.description: After months of defiance, there was defeat. The right-wing government’s success in passing a law that limits the power of the Supreme Court was a gut punch to the largely liberal and secular opposition.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A night of protests and clashes across Israel gave way to a quiet morning, as the Israeli Parliament goes into summer recess.

item.title: Israeli Reservists Threaten to Quit Over Judicial Overhaul
item.description: More than 11,000 Israelis in the military reserve said last week they’d resign if the government’s judicial overhaul went ahead.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Military reservists signing pledges to suspend their voluntary military service during a protest in Tel Aviv last week.

item.title: Ocean Currents in the Atlantic Could Slow by Century’s End, Research Shows
item.description: The system of ocean currents that regulates the climate for a swath of the planet could collapse sooner than expected, a new analysis found.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Sunrise from Miami Beach this month. Atlantic currents that send warm water from the Caribbean toward Europe could be at risk.

item.title: Amid War, Ukrainian Couples Are Divorcing
item.description: The conflict in Ukraine has split apart millions of families. The story of Andrii Shapovalov and Tetiana Shapovalova reveals how a couple’s bond can become a casualty.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Saara Mansikkamaki for NYT; Finbarr O'Reilly for NYT

item.title: Photos: Wildfires in Greece, Italy, Tunisia and Algeria
item.description: Deadly blazes are raging across parts of Southern Europe and North Africa, including the Greek islands and Algeria.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Charred vehicles near the village of Kiotari on the Greek Aegean island of Rhodes on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel’s Protests Over Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul in Photos
item.description: Political turmoil that has been brewing for months reached a crescendo after Parliament passed a law aimed at curbing the power of the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli riot police used water canons to disperse protesters in Tel Aviv on Monday evening.

item.title: Israel’s New Judicial Law Could Threaten Attorney General’s Role
item.description: The law could make it easier for the government to fire the embattled official, Gali Baharav-Miara, who has criticized Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s judicial overhaul.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Gil Cohen Magen
item.media:description: Israel’s attorney general, Gali Baharav-Miara, arriving for the weekly cabinet meeting at the prime minister’s office in Jerusalem this month.

item.title: Global Economy Shows Signs of Resilience Despite Lingering Threats
item.description: The International Monetary Fund upgraded its global growth forecast for 2023.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Eshe Nelson and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: In its latest forecast, the International Monetary Fund’s expects U.S. consumption to begin to wane in the coming months as Americans draw down their savings and interest rates increase further.

item.title: Taliban Shut Afghanistan Beauty Salons, Rare Women’s Public Spaces
item.description: Following through on an order that prompted rare protests in the capital, the Taliban said the services of the women-only businesses violated Shariah law.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: A beautician removing a poster in a salon in Kabul on Monday. Afghanistan had about 12,000 salons, employing 60,000 women.

item.title: What’s Next for Israel After Judicial Overhaul Vote
item.description: The opposition fears a slow descent toward authoritarianism, while the government is waiting to see how disruptive and prolonged the response will be from its critics.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Lawmakers at the Parliament on Monday. The real effects of the law they passed to limit the power of the judiciary could take weeks or months to be clear.

item.title: U.S. Sends More Weapons to Ukraine Amid Slow Counteroffensive
item.description: The package, which includes artillery, air defenses and mine-clearing equipment, will help replenish Ukrainian forces advance through dense Russian minefields and other defenses.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with a Stinger missile in the Kyiv region in May. A new aid package from the United States will include munitions for Stinger antiaircraft systems and other artillery and weapons from Pentagon stockpiles.

item.title: Qin Gang, China’s Foreign Minister, Is Replaced
item.description: Qin Gang, a sometime favorite of Xi Jinping, was replaced by Wang Yi, a seasoned diplomat, leaving many unanswered questions about Qin’s fall.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and David Pierson
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Qin Gang during a news conference in Beijing in March.

item.title: Israel’s Political Crisis
item.description: Now, political leaders will be more powerful and judges less so.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Protesters blocked a highway in Tel Aviv yesterday.

item.title: Ukraine Trains Marines to Fight Russia in Frontline Conditions
item.description: A grueling obstacle course, a few miles from the fighting with Russia, is a final step in the initiation for Ukrainian marines.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marines from Ukraine’s 36th Brigade endured a grueling, seven-kilometer run through obstacles and challenges that simulated what they would meet along the front line of the war.

item.title: The Wind, the Water, the Islands: Exploring Stockholm’s Archipelago
item.description: For Swedes, the archipelago, consisting of more than 20,000 islands, is a quintessential summer destination. Travelers can explore it, too, by ferry and rented boat.
item.dc:creator: Ingrid K. Williams
item.media:credit: Felix Odell for The New York Times
item.media:description: The island of Svartsö in Stockholm’s archipelago.

item.title: Biden Takes His Battle for Democracy Case by Case
item.description: President Biden’s decisions on when to speak out forcefully for democracy can prove tricky.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Protesters against the Israeli government’s judicial overhaul bill gathered at Ben Gurion Airport in Israel earlier this month.

item.title: Typhoon Doksuri Grazes the Philippines on Its Way to China
item.description: Typhoon Doksuri, packing winds equivalent to those of a Category 3 hurricane, is expected to hit China on Friday. It also threatens Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: How Israel’s Supreme Court Might React to the Challenge to Its Power
item.description: The court could strike down the law passed on Monday that seeks to curb its power. Or it might narrowly interpret it. Or it might simply put off any decision.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators near Israel’s Supreme Court building in Jerusalem in March.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Protesters in Jerusalem on Monday night.

item.title: July Heat Waves ‘Virtually Impossible’ Without Climate Change, Study Finds
item.description: The latest study from World Weather Attribution scientists predicts that extreme heat waves will return more frequently.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: Paramedics offered aid during a heat wave this month in Mexicali, Mexico.

item.title: Netanyahu Scores Another Victory, but at What Price?
item.description: The Israeli prime minister has pushed through the first part of his judicial overhaul, but in doing so has deepened a rift in Israeli society and propelled the country into an uncertain new era.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, center, in the Knesset on Monday.

item.title: Israel Adopts Law Weakening Supreme Court
item.description: Complaining of an unaccountable judiciary, the far-right governing coalition, despite months of mass protests, voted to strip the court’s power to override “unreasonable” government actions.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting on Monday night in Tel Aviv against plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to overhaul the Israeli judicial system.

item.title: Russia Strikes Danube Port, Escalating Attacks on Ukraine Grain Routes
item.description: The assault, across the river from Romania, heightened the risk of a more direct confrontation with a NATO member and came on the same day that drones struck buildings in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Andrew Higgins, Andrés R. Martínez, Haley Willis and Tiffany May
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Ukrainian Armed Forces on Monday showing a grain warehouse in a seaport in the Odesa region that was destroyed by a Russian drone strike.

item.title: Putin Signs a Harsh New Law Targeting Transgender People in Russia
item.description: The law, part of a broader L.G.B.T.Q. crackdown, includes a ban on transition surgery.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Russian police officers blocking L.G.B.T.Q. protesters in St. Petersburg in 2019.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Mass Protests in Israel
item.description: Also, political uncertainty in Spain and Twitter’s rebranding.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Tel Aviv last night.

item.title: Protests in Israel Intensify After Vote on Judicial Limits
item.description: Outraged opponents of the government’s removal of some of the Supreme Court’s powers blocked roads around the country. Police responded on horseback and with water cannons.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Protesters in Jerusalem on Monday night.

item.title: Macron’s Lesson After Riots? France Needs Order ‘at Every Level’
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France had outlined 100 days to move past protests over his pension reform, but rioting set off by a fatal police shooting jolted the country once more.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking to the news media on Monday at La Tontouta International Airport in Noumea, the capital of the French territory of New Caledonia.

item.title: What the Collapse of Spain’s Far Right Means Going Forward
item.description: About the only thing clear from Spain’s muddled election results was that Spaniards were turning away from the political extremes.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Supporters of the Spanish far-right Vox party gather outside the party headquarters in Madrid after Spain’s general election on Sunday.

item.title: Greta Thunberg Fined for Disobeying Police at Climate Protest
item.description: The climate activist said that trials like hers brought attention to climate change and that she would continue to protest.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The climate activist Greta Thunberg was carried away by police officers during a protest on Monday in Malmo, Sweden.

item.title: Fires Strike Corfu and Evia in Greece as Rhodes Continues to Burn
item.description: New blazes broke out on Corfu and Evia as tourists were being flown home.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Wildfires near the village of Asklipieio, on the island of Rhodes, Greece, on Monday.
